events.description: Silver prices dropped by 9.6% to below $64.1 per ounce, marking its steepest collapse since 1980.
The nomination of Kevin Warsh as the next Federal Reserve chair.
Silver and other precious metals surged to record highs in January.

facts.fact_text: Silver slid as much as 9.6% to below $64.1 per ounce on Friday.

evidences.evidence_text: Silver slid as much as 9.6% to below $64.1 per ounce on Friday

facts.fact_text: Silver is down approximately 45% from its January 29 peak.

evidences.evidence_text: The white metal is now down roughly 45% from its Jan. 29 peak

facts.fact_text: Kevin Warsh was nominated as the next Fed chair.

evidences.evidence_text: nomination of Kevin Warsh as the next Fed chair

claims.claim_text: Kevin Warsh is considered a more hawkish choice for the Federal Reserve chair.

evidences.evidence_text: nomination of Kevin Warsh as the next Fed chair, widely seen as the more hawkish choice

claims.claim_text: Speculative buying from Chinese traders added froth to the silver rally.

evidences.evidence_text: Speculative buying, particularly from Chinese traders, added froth to the rally

claims.claim_text: Widespread deleveraging and a deepening selloff across financial markets drove the silver price drop.

evidences.evidence_text: sinking to its lowest level in seven weeks amid widespread deleveraging and a deepening selloff across financial markets

evidence.evidence_text: Pressure on precious metals increased further after a sharp rebound in the dollar following the nomination of Kevin Warsh as the next Fed chair, widely seen as the more hawkish choice.
driven by heightened geopolitical risks, economic uncertainty, and concerns over the US Federal Reserve’s independence that fueled safe-haven demand.
Silver’s volatility outpaced other metals as heavy speculative flows overshadowed its supply-demand fundamentals.
Pressure on precious metals increased further after a sharp rebound in the dollar
